chapter_6_The_Optional_Type

Class Recipe_6_4_Optional_flatMap_Versus_map

  • java.lang.Object
    • chapter_6_The_Optional_Type.Recipe_6_4_Optional_flatMap_Versus_map

  • public class Recipe_6_4_Optional_flatMap_Versus_map
extends java.lang.Object

    (6.4.) Optional flatMap Versus map


    1. TO DO

      - avoid wrapping an Optional inside another Optional.

    2. HOW

      - use the Optional.flatMap(Function) method

    3. EQ.

      • extractANameFromAnOptionalManager() - extract a name from an Optional manager
      • anOptionalWrappedInsideAnOptional() - an Optional wrapped inside an Optional
      • anOptionalWrappedInsideAnOptionalWrappedInsideAnOptional() - an Optional wrapped inside an Optional wrapped inside an Optional

    The concept of flatMap is a general one and can be also applied to Optional. The Function argument is applied to each element and produces a single result, in this case of type Optional<U>. If the argument T exists, flatMap applies the function to it and returns an Optional wrapping the contained value. if the argument is not present, the method returns an empty Optional. 
     
 <U> Optional<U> flatMap (Function<? super T, Optional<U>> mapper)
    See Also:
    map and flatMap methods in Stream, wrapping a value inside an Optional, using Optional in a DAO layer, using the map method

      • extractANameFromAnOptionalManager

        protected void extractANameFromAnOptionalManager()
        ◊◊◊ Extract a Name from an Optional Manager ◊◊◊ Get the name of the manager - you either have to get the contained value out of the Optional, or use the map method.
        The map method applies the given function only if the Optional it's called on is not empty. 
         
 public<U> Optional<U> map(Function<? super T, ? extends U> mapper) {
      Objects.requireNonNull(mapper);
      if (!isPresent())
          // Returns Optional.empty but not the value from getBoss(). Doesn't call getBoss().
          return empty();
      else {
          // Gets the value, the name of the Manager and wraps it in an Optional.
          return Optional.ofNullable(mapper.apply(value));
      }
 }
 
 
         
 // No boss set for this department
 System.out.println("\tNo manager set for the department:");
 Department d = new Department();
 // Returns "Unknown"
 System.out.println(d.getBoss().orElse(new Manager("Unknown")).getName());
 // Returns Optional.empty
 System.out.println(d.getBoss().map(Manager::getName));

 // Boss set for this department
 System.out.println("\tManager set for the department:");
 Manager m = new Manager("La la Manager");
 d.setBoss(m);
 // Returns "La la Manager"
 System.out.println(d.getBoss().orElse(new Manager("Unknown")).getName());
 // Returns Optional['La la Manager']
 System.out.println(d.getBoss().map(Manager::getName));

      • anOptionalWrappedInsideAnOptional

        protected void anOptionalWrappedInsideAnOptional()
        ◊◊◊ An Optional Wrapped Inside an Optional ◊◊◊
        Using flatMap flattens the structure, so that you only get a single Optional.
        flatMap doesn't wrap the result in an Optional. 
         
 public<U> Optional<U> flatMap(Function<? super T, Optional<U>> mapper) {
      Objects.requireNonNull(mapper);
      if (!isPresent())
          return empty();
      else {
          // Doesn't wrap the result in an Optional.
          return Objects.requireNonNull(mapper.apply(value));
      }
 }
 
 
         
 Company c = new Company();
 // Returns Optional.empty
 System.out.println(c.getDepartment().flatMap(Department::getBoss).map(Manager::getName));

 Department d = new Department();
 c.setDepartment(d);

 Manager m = new Manager("La la Manager");
 // Returns Optional.empty
 System.out.println(c.getDepartment().flatMap(Department::getBoss).map(Manager::getName));

 d.setBoss(m);
 System.out.println(c.getDepartment()
                     // Optional[Optional[Manager]]
                     .map(Department::getBoss));
 System.out.println(c.getDepartment()
                     // Optional[Manager]
                     .flatMap(Department::getBoss));

 //Optional[La la Manager]
 System.out.println(c.getDepartment() // Optional<Department>
                     .flatMap(Department::getBoss) // Optional<Manager>
                     .map(Manager::getName)); // Optional<String>
        flatMap gets a function with the return type Optional as argument and doesn't wrap the result in an Optional as the result is already an Optional.
        map gets a function with return type U as an argument and wraps the result in an Optional<U>. In this case map(Manager::getName) wraps the String returned by the getName in an Optional<String>

      • anOptionalWrappedInsideAnOptionalWrappedInsideAnOptional

        protected void anOptionalWrappedInsideAnOptionalWrappedInsideAnOptional()
        ◊◊◊ An Optional Wrapped Inside an Optional Wrapped Inside an Optional ◊◊◊ 
         
 Company c = new Company();
 Department d = new Department();
 c.setDepartment(d);
 Manager m = new Manager("La la Manager");
 d.setBoss(m);

 Optional<Company> company = Optional.of(c);
 System.out.println(company // Optional<Company>
                      .flatMap(Company::getDepartment) // Optional<Department>
                      .flatMap(Department::getBoss) // Optional<Manager>
                      .map(Manager::getName)); // Optional<String>
